elements.content: Six new metal–organic frameworks with novel structural features based on a star-like ligand tri(4-pyridylphenyl)amine (TPPA), namely, {[Cd(TPPA)(pht)(H2O)](H2O)2} n (1), {[Zn(TPPA)(pht)](H2O)2} n (2), {[Zn(TPPA)(trans-chdc)0.5(NO3)]·(H2O)} n (3), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]·(H2O)} n (4), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]·(H2O)4} n (5), and {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)]} n (6) (H2pht = phthalic acid, trans-H2chdc = trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, H2bdc = benzene-p-dicarboxylic acid), have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1–3 all exhibit fascinating 2D → 3D frameworks with coexistence of inclined polycatenation and polythreading characters. On the other hand, compounds 4–6 are three supramolecular isomers. Even though the compositions of 4–6 are almost same, they generate different structures. Compound 4 shows a 2D → 3D framework with parallel polycatenation of undulated square layers. Compound 5 reveals 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {4.62}{43.67} crs topology. Compound 6 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D metal–organic polyrotaxane framework. In addition, photophysical properties of 1–3 and the TPPA ligand in the solid state have also been studied.

elements.content: Six new metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) were reported based on a semirigid star-like tri(4-pyridylphenyl)amine (TPPA) ligand. Compounds 1−3 exhibit three 2D → 3D frameworks with coexistence of polycatenation and polythreading, and compounds 4−6 are supramolecular isomers with novel structural features.

elements.content: Functional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are currently of great interest because of their aesthetic structures and potential applications in the fields of photochemical areas, gas adsorption and separation, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and nonlinear optics (NLO). As we know, all applications of MOFs are based on their internal microstructures. However, due to the combined influence of organic ligands, metal ions, solvent systems, and counterions, it still remains a challenge to explore effective synthetic strategies to generate MOFs with expected structures and properties. In this paper, we will investigate generation of MOFs from the aspect of composition and entangled types.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are currently of great interest because of their aesthetic structures and potential applications in the fields of photochemical areas, gas adsorption and separation, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and nonlinear optics (NLO). As we know, all applications of MOFs are based on their internal microstructures. However, due to the combined influence of organic ligands, metal ions, solvent systems, and counterions, it still remains a challenge to explore effective synthetic strategies to generate MOFs with expected structures and properties. In this paper, we will investigate generation of MOFs from the aspect of composition and entangled types.

elements.content: In the aspect of composition, supramolecular isomers including the same composition has gained much attention in the past few years because of their structural diversity and great potential applications. The construction of organic linkers for supramolecular isomers is often affected by several factors such as diversity of coordination modes, flexibility of ligands, and reaction conditions.
elements.clean_text: In the aspect of composition, supramolecular isomers including the same composition has gained much attention in the past few years because of their structural diversity and great potential applications. The construction of organic linkers for supramolecular isomers is often affected by several factors such as diversity of coordination modes, flexibility of ligands, and reaction conditions.

elements.content: In the classes of entangled types, polythreading and polycatenation are interesting structural features of entangled systems, which are noticeable realms of chemistry for its potential application such as energy transfer, drug delivery, and relationship with biological systems. Therefore, coordination networks possessing polythreading and polycatenation features simultaneously have high theoretical and potential practical value.

Therefore, coordination networks possessing polythreading and polycatenation features simultaneously have high theoretical and potential practical value.

elements.content: Compared with benzene- and triazine-centered triangular ligands, the N-centered triangular ligands more easily meet the geometric requirements of metal ions. The coordination polymers based on triphenylamine derivatives have received intense interest due to their fascinating framework topologies and properties. Recently, a triangular N-centered ligand, tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (TIPA, Scheme ), has been investigated intensely in the fields of coordination polymers. Notably, our group has reported an unprecedented 3D cluster polymer based on Mo(W)/Cu/S and TIPA exhibiting strong third-order nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: Herein, we replace three imidazolyl groups of TIPA with three pyridyl groups; then a new star-like ligand, named tri(4-pyridylphenyl)amine (TPPA, Scheme ), was synthesized (Scheme S1, ). Obviously, the flexibility of TPPA is less than that of TIPA because the nitrogen coordination atoms of TPPA are on the axes of benzene–pyridine arms. Due to its weakened flexibility, TPPA ligand may have different coordination modes when coordinating to metal ions, which may induce diverse structures, such as supramolecular isomers.

elements.clean_text: 1  Carboxylate Ligands and N-Containing Ligands

elements.content: We adopted three dicarboxylate ligands with different rigidity, namely, phthalic acid (H2pht), benzene-p-dicarboxylic acid (H2bdc), and trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (trans-H2chdc), as coligands to react with the TPPA ligand and different bivalent metal salts (Scheme ). Six new compounds were obtained under solvothermal conditions, {[Cd(TPPA)(pht)(H2O)](H2O)2} n (1), {[Zn(TPPA)(pht)](H2O)2} n (2), {[Zn(TPPA)(trans-chdc)0.5(NO3)]·(H2O)} n (3), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]·(H2O)} n (4), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]·(H2O)4} n (5), and {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)]} n (6).
elements.clean_text: We adopted three dicarboxylate ligands with different rigidity, namely, phthalic acid (H2pht), benzene-p-dicarboxylic acid (H2bdc), and trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (trans-H2chdc), as coligands to react with the TPPA ligand and different bivalent metal salts (Scheme ). Six new compounds were obtained under solvothermal conditions, {[Cd(TPPA)(pht)(H2O)](H2O)2} n  (1), {[Zn(TPPA)(pht)](H2O)2} n  (2), {[Zn(TPPA)(trans-chdc)0.5(NO3)]⋅(H2O)} n  (3), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]⋅(H2O)} n  (4), {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)(H2O)]⋅(H2O)4} n  (5), and {[Co(TPPA)(bdc)]} n  (6).

elements.content: As we expected, the self-assembly of TPPA and dicarboxylate ligands is an effective method to generate unique architectures and topologies. With the same composition, we obtained three supramolecular isomers 4–6 including a rare 4-fold interpenetrating 3D metal–organic polyrotaxane framework (4). In the aspect of entangled types, we obtained three fascinating 2D → 3D frameworks 1–3 with coexistence of inclined polycatenation and polythreading characters.
elements.clean_text: As we expected, the self-assembly of TPPA and dicarboxylate ligands is an effective method to generate unique architectures and topologies. With the same composition, we obtained three supramolecular isomers 4-6 including a rare 4-fold interpenetrating 3D metal-organic polyrotaxane framework (4). In the aspect of entangled types, we obtained three fascinating 2D → 3D frameworks 1-3 with coexistence of inclined polycatenation and polythreading characters.

elements.content: All compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, X-ray powder diffraction experiments, and X-ray crystallography. The crystal structures and topological analyses of these compounds are investigated and described in detail. Further, the luminescent properties of the TPPA ligand and compounds 1–3 have also been studied.

elements.content: Reagents and solvents employed were commercially available. TPPA ligand was synthesized according to our previous report. All of the samples are stored in mother solutions until the study of properties of 1–6. IR absorption spectra of the compounds were recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Luminescent spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS55 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

Reagents and solvents employed were commercially available. TPPA ligand was synthesized according to our previous report. All of the samples are stored in mother solutions until the study of properties of 1-6. IR absorption spectra of the compounds were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets. C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. Luminescent spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS55 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·6H2O (30.1 mg, 0.1 mmol), TPPA (47.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), and phthalic acid (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF/MeCN/H2O (1:2:3). The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 95 °C for 3 days. Pale yellow crystals of 1 were collected in 69% yield (based on TPPA ligand). Calcd for CdC41H34N4O7: C, 61.01%; H, 4.25%; N, 6.94%. Found: C, 60.96%; H, 4.28%; N, 6.98%. elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. X-ray crystallographic data for 4, 5, and 6 were collected at room temperature by way of sealing the better single crystals in a quartz tube with mother liquor. X-ray crystallographic data of these compounds were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the (Table S1). A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS. The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystallographic data for 1, 2, and 3 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. X-ray crystallographic data for 4, 5, and 6 were collected at room temperature by way of sealing the better single crystals in a quartz tube with mother liquor. X-ray crystallographic data of these compounds were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structures and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in the  (Table S1). A semiempirical absorption correction was applied using SADABS. The topological analysis and some diagrams were produced using the TOPOS program.

The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in orthorhombic crystal system of Pbcn. The local coordination geometry around the Cd2+ atom is depicted in Figure . The Cd1 atom coordinates to two N atoms from different TPPA ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and four oxygen atoms from two distinct deprotonated phthalic acids. Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of {[Cd(TPPA)(pht)(H2O)](H2O)2} n  (1)

The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in orthorhombic crystal system of Pbcn. The local coordination geometry around the Cd2+ atom is depicted in Figure . The Cd1 atom coordinates to two N atoms from different TPPA ligands, one oxygen atom from the coordinated water molecule, and four oxygen atoms from two distinct deprotonated phthalic acids. The Cd-O lengths are in the range of 2.212(3)-2.587(3) Å and Cd-N lengths are 2.238(4)-2.253(4) Å, which are all similar to the values found in other Cd(II) complexes. As shown in Figure a, there are two deprotonated phthalic acid coordinated by two neighboring Cd(II) cations on the symmetrical position, forming a 14-membered ring.

elements.clean_text: 1  Coordination environment of the Cd2+ atoms in 1. Most hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity (30% ellipsoid probability). Symmetry codes: #1 = 2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z; #2 = 0.5 + x, -0.5 - y, 0.5 - z.

elements.content: Each 14-membered ring was connected with four pyridine groups from four TPPA ligands to form an undulating 2D network (Figure b). For each TPPA ligand, two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from two pyridine groups were coordinated by two Cd atoms, while the remaining nitrogen atom (N3) from the remaining pyridine group did not coordinate with any atoms. One fascinating structural feature of complex 1 is that the phenyl–pyridyl arms with free nitrogen atoms on the two sides of one 2D layer network thread into two adjacent parallel 2D layer networks (Figure c), confirming that complex 1 possesses polythreading character.

elements.content: Better insight into these 2D layer frameworks can be accessed by the topological method. Each [Cd2(pht)2(H2O)2] unit (Figure a), including the 14-membered ring, can be simplified as 4-connecting nodes, and the TPPA ligand in bidentate mode can be considered as a linker. Then, the 2D layer frameworks in complex 1 can be simplified to a (4,4) rhombic grid coordination polymer layer with sql topology (Figure d). Packing of the layers generates two sets of layers oriented toward different directions. Each of the two adjacent layers are catenated by two other adjacent windows from another layer in the other set. That is, these two sets of layers catenate to each other in a parallel–parallel arrangement to form a 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation structure.

elements.content: There is an obvious difference of the coordination modes of metal atoms in 1 and 2 (Figure and Figure a). Each Zn atom in 2 coordinates to two N atoms from different TPPA ligands and four oxygen atoms from two distinct deprotonated phthalic acids. No water molecules coordinated to the Zn atom in 2. Nevertheless, complexes 1 and 2 are isostructural from the topological viewpoint. There are also 14-membered rings consisting of deprotonated phthalic acid coordinated by two neighboring Zn atoms in 2, as shown in Figure b. Each [Zn2(pht)2] unit in 2 also connects to four N atoms from different TPPA ligands (Figure b). Because the other structure features are very similar to those of complex 1, we do not describe them any further. Single 2D net, 2D layers accumulated toward a single direction, and schematic view of the sql topology of 3 are depicted in Figures S1–S3 of .

elements.content: Each TPPA ligand links two Zn atoms, acting as a linker to form a 1D wavelike chain (Figure a). Adjacent chains are linked by trans-chdc2– anions to form a single 2D network (Figure a,b). Just like 1 and 2, two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) from two pyridine groups were coordinated by two Cd atoms, while the remaining nitrogen atom (N2) from the remaining pyridine group did not coordinate with any atoms for each TPPA ligand. The phenyl–pyridyl arms with free nitrogen atoms on the two sides of one 2D layer network also thread into two adjacent parallel 2D layer networks (Figure c), confirming that compound 3 shows polythreading character. Therefore, the crystal structures of 1–3 all exhibit polythreading character.

elements.content: Both of the TPPA ligand and trans-chdc2– anions can be simplified as linkers. The 2D layer frameworks in compound 3 can be simplified to a Shubnikov hexagonal plane net with hcb topology (Figure d). Packing of the layers generates two sets of layers oriented in different directions. Each of the two adjacent layers in 3 are catenated by two other adjacent windows from another layer in the other set. That is, these two sets of layers catenate to each other in a parallel–parallel arrangement to form a 2D → 3D inclined polycatenation structure. We confirm that compounds 1–3 all show polycatenation features. To the best of our knowledge, crystal structures with coexisting polythreading and polycatenation features are highly rare till now.

elements.content: The coordination modes of the two carboxylate groups from the bdc2– anion are different in 4: monodentate (O3) and chelate (O1, O2). Adjacent Co atoms are linked by bdc2– anions to generate Co–carboxylate chains. The chains are further extended by TPPA ligands in bidentate modes, resulting in a simple puckered sql (square layer) network (Figure a,b).
elements.clean_text: The coordination modes of the two carboxylate groups from the bdc2- anion are different in 4: monodentate (O3) and chelate (O1, O2). Adjacent Co atoms are linked by bdc2- anions to generate Co-carboxylate chains. The chains are further extended by TPPA ligands in bidentate modes, resulting in a simple puckered sql (square layer) network (Figure a,b).

elements.content: There is a large window in the puckered sheet with dimensions of 19.2 × 10.6 Å (Figure a,b). Within the sheet, the Co atoms are not all coplanar; rather, half fall in one plane and half in the other parallel plane. The puckered nature of the sheets with large square windows may offer a good chance to form a polycatenated network. Indeed, in 4, each layer is entangled directly by two adjacent sql layers left and right, as shown in Figure c. The mode of polycatenation is shown in Figure d, where the TPPA linkers of one layer pass through the cavity of the others. As far as we know, only a few examples of dimensionality increasing from 2D layers to overall 3D entanglements have been observed for parallel polycatenation systems so far.

elements.content: The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 5 crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system of P21/n. The local coordination geometry around the Co2+ atom can be described as a {CoN3O3} distorted octahedron, with the axial positions occupied by one oxygen atom from one coordinated water molecule and one N donor atom from one TPPA ligand (Figure ). The equatorial plane consists of two N donor atoms from another two TPPA ligands and two oxygen atoms from two bdc2– ligands. TPPA ligands are coordinated to the Co2+ atom to form a 2D hexagonal grid with planar layers (Figure a). Such layers are further connected by bdc2– ligands (Figure b), leading to the formation of a 3D framework.

elements.content: The Co2+ atom can be regarded as a five-connected node, the TPPA ligand can be considered as a three-connected node (distances of N4 and Co, 10.654–10.683 Å), and each bdc2– ligand can be considered as a linear linker (distances of corresponding Co–Co, 11.352 and 11.538 Å), thus forming a (3,5)-connected network (Figure d). There is also a channel with a cross section of approximately 11 × 24 Å in the single network (Figure c). The channel is so large that the two other 3D frameworks can be accommodated in this channel (Figure e,f). According to a calculation performed using PLATON, complex 5 contains a solvent-accessible void space of 27.0% of the total crystal volume. The Schläfli symbol for this binodal net is {4.62}{43.67}, and the topology type of this net is crs (Figure e).

The Co1 atom coordinates to three oxygen atoms from two distinct bdc2- anions and three N atoms from three different TPPA ligands; thus, the Co2+ atoms can be considered as 5-connecting nodes. elements.content: In structure 6, two adjacent parallel chains are joined by two bdc2– ligands. Meanwhile, both bdc2– ligands are joined by one Co2+ atom. Another 1D ladder-like chain is joined with the same Co2+ atom. Finally, a single 3D framework is created by repeating these linkages (Figure b). Rectangular channels exist (Figure c) with a cross section of approximately 20 × 20 Å (excluding van der Waals radii) in the single 3D framework. So the channel is large enough to accommodate three other equivalent ones (Figure d), giving rise to a 4-fold interpenetrating framework. Upon interpenetration, compound 6 contains a small solvent-accessible void space of 4.5% of the total crystal volume calculated by PLATON. The Schläfli symbol for this binodal net is {42.65.83}{42.6}, and the topology type of this net is 3,5T1 (Figure e).

elements.content: The ladder-like chain in 6 (Figure a) can be considered as a successions of loops, and deprotonated bdc2– acids can be considered as rods threading the loops, indicating that compound 6 possesses the rare, fascinating polyrotaxane character. To the best of our knowledge, only a few interpenetrating 3D metal–organic polyrotaxane frameworks have been reported.

elements.content: Supramolecular isomerism refers to two or more supramolecular systems that have the same composition and building blocks but generate different architectures. As we can see, different supramolecular structures 4–6 are all mainly constructed from Co atoms, deprotonated benzene-p-dicarboxylic acid anions, and TPPA molecules. Moreover, the ratios of the three compositions are all the same (1:1:1). Therefore, we should consider compounds 4–6 as supramolecular isomers, despite of the existence of different coordinated or free water molecules. Although one-pot synthesis of two or more coordinated polymers has been reported, one-pot synthesis of two supramolecular isomers is rare, and such synthesis of three supramolecular isomers is much less.
elements.clean_text:
Supramolecular Isomeric Nature of compounds 4-6 

Supramolecular isomerism refers to two or more supramolecular systems that have the same composition and building blocks but generate different architectures. As we can see, different supramolecular structures 4-6 are all mainly constructed from Co atoms, deprotonated benzene-p-dicarboxylic acid anions, and TPPA molecules. Moreover, the ratios of the three compositions are all the same (1:1:1). Therefore, we should consider compounds 4-6 as supramolecular isomers, despite of the existence of different coordinated or free water molecules. Although one-pot synthesis of two or more coordinated polymers has been reported, one-pot synthesis of two supramolecular isomers is rare, and such synthesis of three supramolecular isomers is much less.

elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

Luminescent compounds are of great interest due to their various appliatoms in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Compounds 1-3 are insoluble in common organic solvents; hence photoluminescence properties of 1-3 and free TPPA ligand were investigated in the solid state at room temperature (Figure  and Table ).

elements.content: Emission spectra of free TPPA ligand and 1–3 in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 12  Emission spectra of free TPPA ligand and 1-3 in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the free TPPA ligand exhibits an intense emission between 480 and 600 nm (λmax = 525 nm upon excitation at 420 nm), which originated from charge transfer of the internal TPPA ligand. Two emission peaks can be observed for both of 1 and 2. The peaks in the range of 440–490 nm for 1 and 2 can be ascribed to the π*−π transitions between deprotonated phthalic acid and TPPA ligand upon metal coordination to different degrees. The peaks in the range of 490–600 nm for 1 and 2 should be attributed to the charge transfer of the internal TPPA ligand. In comparison to free TPPA ligands, the slightly blue shift of emission of 2 can be ascribed to the weak π*−π transitions of the TPPA ligands upon metal coordination. Because luminescent emission of trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid is negligible, there is almost no π*−π transitions between deprotonated trans-1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid and TPPA ligand, and we did not observe an obvious peak in the range of 440–490 nm. The single emission peak in the range of 490–600 nm for compound 3 can be attributed to the charge transfer of the internal TPPA ligand. In comparison to free TPPA ligands, the red shift of emission of 3 can be ascribed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) transitions.

The luminescent decay curves were fitted with a double-exponential decay function: fit = A + B 1 exp(−t/τ1) + B 2 exp(−t/τ2).

Furthermore, the emission decay lifetimes of 1–3 and free TPPA ligand were monitored. The luminescent decay curves (Figures S9–S14, ) can be fitted with a double-exponential decay function. The results are summarized in Table . Emission lifetime values (τ1 and τ2) are both higher than the corresponding values of 1–3, indicating that the emission of 1–3 can be mostly attributed to the charge transfer of the internal TPPA ligand. For compound 1, the emission lifetime values for emission at 527 nm are higher than the values for emission at 460 nm, indicating that emission of charge transfer of the internal TPPA ligand is longer than emission of π*−π transitions between the carboxylate ligand and TPPA ligand, as well as compound 2.

elements.content: To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials tested in photochemical studies, PXRD experiments were carried out for compounds 1–3. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the compounds 1–3 are shown in the , Figures S4–S6, and they show that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals for 1–3 are the same.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD Results

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials tested in photochemical studies, PXRD experiments were carried out for compounds 1-3. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the compounds 1-3 are shown in the , Figures S4-S6, and they show that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals for 1-3 are the same.

elements.content: In summary, as we expected, the self-assembly of TPPA and carboxylate ligands is an effective method to generate aesthetic architectures and topologies. In this work, six new metal–organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by the self-assembly of TPPA ligand, carboxylate ligands (H2pht, H2bdc, or trans-H2chdc), and various metal ions under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1–4 reveal fascinating 2D → 3D structures. Compounds 1–3 exhibit coexisting inclined polycatenation and polythreading characters. Compounds 4–6 are three supramolecular isomers. Even though the compositions of 4–6 are the same, they generate different structures. Compound 4 shows a 2D → 3D framework with parallel polycatenation of undulated square layers (sql). Compound 5 reveals 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {4.62}{43.67} crs topology. Compound 6 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D metal–organic polyrotaxane framework. Further study about this star-like tri(4-pyridylphenyl)amine ligand is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, as we expected, the self-assembly of TPPA and carboxylate ligands is an effective method to generate aesthetic architectures and topologies. In this work, six new metal-organic frameworks have been successfully synthesized by the self-assembly of TPPA ligand, carboxylate ligands (H2pht, H2bdc, or trans-H2chdc), and various metal ions under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1-4 reveal fascinating 2D → 3D structures. Compounds 1-3 exhibit coexisting inclined polycatenation and polythreading characters. Compounds 4-6 are three supramolecular isomers. Even though the compositions of 4-6 are the same, they generate different structures. Compound 4 shows a 2D → 3D framework with parallel polycatenation of undulated square layers (sql). Compound 5 reveals 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks with {4.62}{43.67} crs topology. Compound 6 shows a 4-fold interpenetrating 3D metal-organic polyrotaxane framework. Further study about this star-like tri(4-pyridylphenyl)amine ligand is in progress.

cln_elements.content:
The Co2+ atom can be regarded as a five-connected node, the TPPA ligand can be considered as a three-connected node (distances of N4 and Co, 10.654–10.683 Å), and each bdc2– ligand can be considered as a linear linker (distances of corresponding Co–Co, 11.352 and 11.538 Å), thus forming a (3,5)-connected network (Figure d). There is also a channel with a cross section of approximately 11 × 24 Å in the single network (Figure c). The channel is so large that the two other 3D frameworks can be accommodated in this channel (Figure e,f). According to a calculation performed using PLATON, complex 5 contains a solvent-accessible void space of 27.0% of the total crystal volume. The Schläfli symbol for this binodal net is {4.62}{43.67}, and the topology type of this net is crs (Figure e).

In structure 6, two adjacent parallel chains are joined by two bdc2– ligands. Meanwhile, both bdc2– ligands are joined by one Co2+ atom. Another 1D ladder-like chain is joined with the same Co2+ atom. Finally, a single 3D framework is created by repeating these linkages (Figure b). Rectangular channels exist (Figure c) with a cross section of approximately 20 × 20 Å (excluding van der Waals radii) in the single 3D framework. So the channel is large enough to accommodate three other equivalent ones (Figure d), giving rise to a 4-fold interpenetrating framework. Upon interpenetration, compound 6 contains a small solvent-accessible void space of 4.5% of the total crystal volume calculated by PLATON. The Schläfli symbol for this binodal net is {42.65.83}{42.6}, and the topology type of this net is 3,5T1 (Figure e).

So the channel is large enough to accommodate three other equivalent ones (Figure d), giving rise to a 4-fold interpenetrating framework. Upon interpenetration, compound 6 contains a small solvent-accessible void space of 4.5% of the total crystal volume calculated by PLATON. The Schläfli symbol for this binodal net is {42.65.83}{42.6}, and the topology type of this net is 3,5T1 (Figure e).
